comment.author: 51588910@N08
comment._content: This was one of Warrenpoint's famous "Fair days" an old advert is displayed here: www.oldwarrenpointforum.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=20&... There are many references to the fair days on the oldwarrenpoint forum even some from the Town commissioners Minutes when they allocated part of the square: "19th January 1883 The site for the sheep fair was fixed from the corner of Church Street to the corner of Post Office street. (This was a change and placards were to be erected with “Cow Fair” “Horse Fair” and “Sheep Fair”" Minutes from the town commissioners 1882-1899 www.oldwarrenpointforum.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=3&...

comment.author: 77199267@N03

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] That beaded pole is the famous beaded pole of the Warrenpoint fly tyers club, founded 1904 which ties ( pardon the pun) in with your dates. The beads are used to make wet flies a little heavier so that they allow the flies to sink through the surface film thus allowing the flies to fish at different levels in the river. 1 bead for just below the surface 4 beads for just off the bottom. You can see the same beads being used in your picture from Killarney, a few months back. 

These beads are usually used at May Fly time so I would say that we are talking about circa 20th May 1905 IMHO  .. Have a great weekend.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Sneaking in a chalet de necessite when you think I'm not looking, eh?

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] the WFTC are also known to use dog hair for some of their famous flies, which is no surprise given the number of dogs in this photo. Their most famous patterns include the Collie Dog ( google it),  the Black Lab Zulu, and of course the Beagle Bead.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: www.oldwarrenpointforum.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=14&amp... Scroll half way down the page - they talk about (and show) a sister photo taken on the same day? Edit Having looked at both I do not think it is the same day.

comment.author: 51588910@N08
comment._content: Yes, I also thought that but when I was given (and posted) the pictures in 2008 that is what I was told - if not the same day then they are very close together and I thought myself that the "hobby horses" were hidden by the tree's in the other photo as the sheep pen seems to be in the same place. If the one posted here is in the archives than I imagine the others are as well (the library does have an extensive amount of Warrenpoint pictures) so would not be too hard to check a better copy :-)

comment.author: 51588910@N08
comment._content: Also, the post box is still visible outside what is now the Ulster bank in the photo, and was still there in the 1940's and 50's before being removed. In fact, (useless information coming up) right up until the 1980's the "second" post bag(s) for Warrenpoint was brought down from Newry on an Ulsterbus, and as a young postman I often had to be back from my rounds to collect it from the bus as they stopped there but not outside the post office in Church Street.

comment.author: 51588910@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] the object you ask about (is it for navigation) is a gas lamp. The base of which survived for years and when the square was "upgraded" they put a reproduction up in its place. I don't think any parts of the original survive but I may be wrong - I'll take another look at it later. You can just make out the new one in this google streetview link taken from about the same area as the actual photo - going by the position, I would guess the original was taken from the former Crown Hotel (or one of the buildings beside it) goo.gl/maps/rsXnI
